docs.abstract: Jane E Brody article on 'health sins' that can reduce one's chances for long and healthy life (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Seven Deadly Sins have taken on a new--and, from the standpoint of your health, a more important--look. Gluttony (as evidenced by obesity) and sloth (physical inactivity) remain the same, but pride, covetousness, lust, anger and envy have been replaced by "sins" that more accurately reflect your chances for a long and healthy life.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Seven Deadly Sins have taken on a new - and, from the standpoint of your health, a more important - look. Gluttony (as evidenced by obesity) and sloth (physical inactivity) remain the same, but pride, covetousness, lust, anger and envy have been replaced by ''sins'' that more accurately reflect your chances for a long and healthy life. The new sins are smoking cigarettes, drinking alcohol immoderately, regularly sleeping more than eight or less than seven hours a night, failing to eat breakfast regularly and snacking between meals. Added to weighing too much or too little and failing to exercise regularly, these poor health habits have been shown in a nine-year study of 6,928 Californians to set the stage for an early death.

headline.main: Fertility of Captive Apes: Success Is Greater When Female Has Her Way; Dominance by Males Hinders Ape Fertility Gorillas Suffer Most Artificial Insemination May Help

docs.abstract: Primatologists meet in Atlanta to discuss problems and experiments with infertility among captive apes, hoping for insights into human behavior; examples in which fertility was enhanced by changing apes' surroundings or partners cited; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA SCIENTISTS investigating why the great apes, man's closest relatives, have such low rates of reproduction in captivity have found that the large primates may be more like humans than previously thought.
docs.snippet: ATLANTA SCIENTISTS investigating why  the great apes, man's closest relatives, have such low rates of reproduction in captivity have  found that the large primates may be more like humans than previously thought.

headline.main: FERTILITY OF CAPTIVE APES: SUCCESS IS GREATER WHEN FEMALE HAS HER WAY

docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA SCIENTISTS investigating why the great apes, man's closest relatives, have such low rates of reproduction in captivity have found that the large primates may be more like humans than previously thought. In addition to having chromosomal similarities, ''language'' learning abilities and other signs of human-like intelligence, chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans in captivity have also been found to have fertility handicaps. The findings were reported here at a recent conference initiated by primatologists who are concerned about the low and possibly declining fertility of captive anthropoid apes.
